PrescribingInteractionClass.name: Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs
PrescribingInteractionClass.description: NSAIDs are considered to nonspecifically inhibit both cyclooxygenase (COX)-1 and COX-2. NSAIDs are generally protein bound and may interact with other protein bound drugs.

InteractionClass.name: Potassium sparing diuretics
InteractionClass.description: These drugs inhibit sodium-potassium exchange in the distal tubule.

Interaction.Professional: Coadministration of diuretics with nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs)may reduce the antihypertensive and diuretic effects of diuretics. This may be due to impaired prostaglandin synthesis which may lead to salt and water retention. Studies have shown that concurrent use led to decreased natriuretic effects of diuretics. Additionally, NSAIDs also have nephrotoxic effects which may be exacerbated by diuretic therapy. The addition of an ACE inhibitor to this combination (NSAID + diuretic) will further increase the risk of renal impairment, especially in the elderly. Monitor concurrent use and increase the dose of diuretic if needed.

Additionally, NSAIDs also have nephrotoxic effects which may be exacerbated by diuretic therapy. The addition of an ACE inhibitor to this combination (NSAID + diuretic) will further increase the risk of renal impairment, especially in the elderly. Monitor concurrent use and increase the dose of diuretic if needed.
